G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u00a7 14 and 15.proposition: Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 186, §§ 14 and 15, provides tenants with a covenant of quiet enjoyment, mandating that landlords must not interfere with a tenant’s reasonable use and enjoyment of their residence.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every Massachusetts lease includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment by implied law, granting tenants the right to possession, use, and enjoyment of their rental property without substantial interference by the landlord.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held landlords liable for breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in cases involving similar factual circumstances, including the failure to provide safe and habitable premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies and interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory quiet enjoyment provision) to hold that a landlord can be liable where unsanitary, uninhabitable conditions—here, repeated flooding with water and sewage—interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. The court explicitly situates § 14 within a body of Massachusetts statutes and cases imposing duties on landlords to provide safe and sanitary housing, and affirms that liability for quiet enjoyment can be based on the landlord’s reckless failure to maintain habitable, code-compliant premises. Although the quiet enjoyment damages award was vacated as duplicative, the court’s reasoning clearly recognizes such liability in factual circumstances involving unsafe and unsanitary conditions.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing. … These statutes are designed to facilitate enforcement of State housing regulations and to provide relief for tenants deprived of decent homes. … The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey…; Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway…. The jury found … that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held landlords liable for breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in cases involving similar factual circumstances, including the failure to provide safe and habitable premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion does not say that Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held landlords liable for breaches of quiet enjoyment in similar factual contexts. Instead, it narrows liability by holding that a mere statutory lead paint violation, without proof of at least negligence and notice, is not enough to constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. While it cites earlier cases (Simon, Cruz, Darmetko, Dorgan) as examples where defects and habitability issues led to § 14 liability, this case itself clarifies that additional landlord fault is required, undermining any characterization of automatic or strict liability for failure to provide safe and habitable premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held landlords liable for breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in cases involving similar factual circumstances, including the failure to provide safe and habitable premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does involve a landlord’s liability for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not reflect a line of “repeated” Massachusetts decisions in “similar factual circumstances,” nor does it tie such liability to the broader concept of failing to provide “safe and habitable premises.” Instead, it recognizes, in this specific context of pervasive criminal drug activity in common areas, that the landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 if it fails to take reasonable measures to remove disruptive nontenants. The opinion also expressly narrows the warranty of habitability to physical conditions, rejecting an argument that security obligations fall under that warranty. Thus, it cannot accurately be cited for the broader, repeated-holdings proposition stated.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14. There must be a trial to determine what, if any, measures the defendant has taken to remove nontenants engaged in unlawful activity and to determine the seriousness or substantiality of the interference with the tenancies. If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action… then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment….”
